columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the capital gains yield based on the dividend yield of each of the four given stocks.

Before we solve, we first need to list down the given values that will be used.

For Stock W:

|Dividend |$3.75 | 
|--|--| 
| Growth rate|10% | 
| Rate of return|13% | 

For Stock X:
|Dividend |$3.75 | 
|--|--| 
| Growth rate|0% | 
| Rate of return|13% | 

For Stock Y:
|Dividend |$3.75 | 
|--|--| 
| Growth rate|-5% | 
| Rate of return|13% | 

Stock Z will use a different method of solving so we will discuss the given later on.

For Stock W:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1+0.10}{0.13-0.10}\\[15pt]
&=\$137.50
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock X:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1+0}{0.13-0}\\[15pt]
&=\$28.85
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock Y:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1-0.05}{0.13+0.05}\\[15pt]
&=\$19.79
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the prices, we can now solve for the dividend yield using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\text{Dividend}\times\dfrac{1+\text{Growth rate}}{\text{Price}}
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock W:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1+0.10}{\$137.50}\\[15pt]
&=0.03
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock X:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1+0}{\$28.85}\\[15pt]
&=0.13
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock Y:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1-0.05}{\$19.79}\\[15pt]
&=0.18
\end{aligned}$$

To get the capital gains yield, we can simply subtract the dividend yield from the required rate of return.

For Stock W:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=0.13-0.03\\
&=0.10
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock X:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=0.13-0.13\\
&=0.0
\end{aligned}$$

For Stock Y:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=0.13-0.18\\
&=0.05
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will solve for the necessary information for Stock Z. But first, we will list down the given values that will be relevant in the solution:


| Dividend|$3.75 | 
|--|--| 
|Initial growth rate |20% | 
|Number of years for the initial rate |2 years | 
|Growth rate after initial |5% | 
|Rate of return |13% |

From the price, we can now proceed with solving for the dividend yield by using the same formula in Step 6:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\$3.75 \times \dfrac{1-0.20}{\$70.875}\\[15pt]
&=0.0423
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the dividend yield, we can simply substitute this from the required rate of return to get the capital gains yield.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=0.13-0.0423\\[15 pt]
&=0.0877
\end{aligned}$$

The capital gains yield of Stock Z is $0.0877$.

In summary, here are the capital gains yield for each of the given stocks:


|Stock |Capital Gains Yield | 
|--|--| 
|W | 0.10| 
| X| 0.00| 
|Y | 0.05| 
|Z |0.0877 |

As we can see from the given data, the capital gains yield is simply the difference between the required rate of return and the dividend yield. This means that the growth rate, when solving for the dividend yield, plays the biggest role in dictating the capital gains yield of each of the stocks.
